title: Orientalist Paintings From the Najd Collection Head to Auction
text:
Text size

The anonymous Middle East collector of the Najd Collection of orientalist art is selling 40 works he acquired in the 1970s and ’80s for an estimated £25 million to £40 million (US$30.1 million to US$48.2 million) at a Sotheby’s auction in London next month.

The entire collection of 155 works has been known to scholars and collectors since at least 1991, when the paintings were compiled in a book with guidance from the late London art dealer Brian MacDermot.

Orientalist art refers to richly colored, detailed, and, some have argued, romanticized works depicting life in the Ottoman Empire, North Africa, and the Middle East, that were largely painted by 19th century European artists.

“It’s a collection that really sets the benchmark by which to compare Orientalist art of the very best kind,” says Claude Piening, Sotheby’s head of 19th century European paintings. “It’s a collection we’ve dreamt of seeing in the flesh let alone handling for sale.”

Osman Hamdy Bey's 'Koranic Instruction,' 1890. Courtesy of Sotheby's

The Najd Collection includes works from 44 artists, although half are by three key painters of the period: Jean-Léon Gérôme of France, and Ludwig Deutsch and Rudolph Ernst of Austria.

“Technically speaking, and in terms of the quality, and amazing colorful and vivid palettes, these artists really stand out,” Piening says.

While 40 works will be offered—at what Sotheby’s says is the highest estimated value for an orientalist sale—all 155 in the collection will be shown together for the first time from Oct. 11-15 at the auction house’s London gallery.

Currently, highlights are on tour, with 10 from the sale on view at Sotheby’s galleries in New York. This same grouping will move to Los Angeles in mid-September, while a second group of 10 will be exhibited in Dubai and Paris. The 40 works will be sold in a dedicated auction the evening of Oct. 22, marking the first time Sotheby’s has placed the category in an evening sale.

The Middle Eastern individual behind the collection was among the first from the region to collect orientalist art, coming across the works initially at Mathaf Gallery in London, where MacDermont specialized in the genre.

“He is a very open-minded individual who was ahead of his curve in his part of the world in collecting this material,” Piening says. “Before, orientalist art was really the preserve of Western collectors—almost all the pictures are by Western artists and were made originally for Western consumption.”

That’s largely because artists from the region in the 19th century “were more involved with craft, and geometric art, rather than painting in the Western sense of the word,” he says. Photography was a new medium at the time, so other than the works of the orientalists, “there is very little visual record of how the Middle East, North Africa, and Turkey, looked at this time in history,” Piening adds.

Orientalist art has been criticized for unrealistic or exoticized depictions of Islamic life. A British Museum show of orientalist art that will run at the same time as the auction describes the genre as “often blurring the lines between fantasy and reality.” Inspired by the east: how the Islamic world influenced western art will be shown from Oct. 10 to Jan. 26.

Piening says observations of exoticism often stem from paintings that were “figments of the imagination,” typically of artists who had not even traveled to the region.

The artists represented in the Najd Collection, however, all traveled to Middle East, North Africa, or Turkey, and while some include the artistic license of a painter—such as showing individuals praying at the same time in different positions versus in tandem—it was often done as a deliberate device to educate people in the West, he says.

Among the highlights for sale is Gérôme’s Riders Crossing the Desert, 1870, a painting of vivid red, blue, and shades of brown, depicting an Egyptian desert scene. It was painted a year after the Suez Canal opened, making the region more accessible. The work carries an estimate between £3 million and £5 million.

German artist Gustav Bauernfeind's Market in Jaffa, 1887, with an estimate between £2.5 million and £3.5 million, will be one of the artist’s best works to appear on the international market, Sotheby’s says.

“It is a true tour de force that showcases Bauernfiend’s great skill at rendering the local architecture and the hustle and bustle of a busy street,” the auction house said in a Thursday news release.

The works for sale also include examples from the Turkish artist Osman Hamdy Bey, the only Middle Eastern painter to have worked in this same Western style, which he brought back to his country.

Hamdy Bey’s Koranic Instruction, 1890, which carries an estimate between £3 million and £5 million, depicts a sleepy, seated pupil.

“On the face of it, [Koranic Instruction] looks similar [to European orientalist art], but because it’s painted from the point of a view of an insider, there are references and puns, and little satirical elements, that only he as a Muslim could convey and express,” Piening says.

For instance, in Islamic text on the painting, Hamdy Bey included the world ‘sleeping,’—“just poking a little bit of fun, lightening the mood,” he says.
description: Sotheby’s to sell 40 of 155 works of the well-known grouping at October evening sale in London
